issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to access the children list directly via a public field (person.children), but both the template and the solution define children as a private field with a getter (private Set<Person> children; public Set<Person> getChildren()). This mismatch will cause students who follow the problem text to try to access person.children and encounter a compilation error or confusion because the field is not public.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the artifacts consistent. Preferred fix: update the problem statement to instruct students to use the provided getter (person.getChildren()) instead of accessing a public field, e.g. replace the sentence on line 3 with: "Access the children list via person.getChildren() (use the getter)." Alternative (less recommended): change the children field in the template and solution to be public (public Set<Person> children) and adjust any existing getter usage in tests/service to match — but updating the problem text preserves encapsulation and matches existing code/tests.

issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to access the children list directly via the public field syntax `person.children` (line 3 of problem statement). However, both the template and solution Person classes declare the children collection as a private field with a getter (private Set<Person> children; plus getChildren()). This makes the advice in the problem statement impossible to follow without changing the provided code and will confuse students about the intended access pattern (field access vs. getter).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the instruction with the code. Either (a) change the problem statement to instruct students to use the provided accessor (person.getChildren()) instead of direct field access, or (b) deliberately expose the field in the template/solution by making the children field public (e.g., public Set<Person> children) and document this choice. Prefer option (a) to follow Java encapsulation conventions: update the problem text to say 'access the children list via person.getChildren() (use the getter)'.
